_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY





Introduction and Policies



The Dogwood Gas Processing Facility, owned and operated by Plains Gas Solutions, LLC ("Plains"), is committed to the same brand of safety and environmental excellence that all other Plains assets promote. This philosophy involves making each and every employee and contractor accountable for their own safety as well as that of the community around them. As a company we follow a close adherence to all applicable federal, state and local laws to ensure a safe and healthy environment for all. 



Employees who enter the Plains facility complete a thorough training, both in the classroom and on-the-job, that enables them to address emergency issues as they arise. This preparation includes standard operational, emergency operational, and release prevention training. In addition, periodic refresher courses help to keep operators' problem solving abilities up to date and in sync with our recurring safety improvements. Our regular internal audits provide an excellent checks and balances system for monitoring these high standards that we set.



The plant is a gas processing facility. The Plains Dogwood Gas Plant operates a variety of processes to recover natural gas liquids from natural gas, and the facility treats the natural gas to meet pipeline specifications. There are no threshold quantities of toxic substances present, although there is hydrogen sulfide at the facility. The pressurized NGL tank contains the regulated substance at the facility. The facility is classified as Program Level 1 under the regulation. The purpose of this Risk Management Plan (RMPlan) is to provide information about our operations at the facility, our programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, our emergency response plans in case an accidental release should occur, our 5 year accident history (new facility, so no incident history), and our planned changes to improve safety at the facility.



Worst Case and Alternative Release Scenarios

As specified by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) RMP Regulations, our worst-case release scenario for flammables would be the loss of all of the pressurized NGL from the NGL tank causing a vapor cloud explosion. 



An alternate release scenario is not required for a Program Level 1 facility.



We have discussed these potential hydrocarbon releases with our employees and with local emergency response officials in Escambia County, thereby further reducing the possibility of any impact on the public.



Prevention Program



The following is a summary of the accident prevention program in place at the Plains Dogwood Gas Plant Facility. The processes at the plant are regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) Risk Management Program (RMP) and are also subject to the OSHA PSM. Since the facility is subject to Program Level 1 requirements, the overall prevention program is complying with the emergency management requirements in the regulation (see next paragraph).





Emergency Response Program



In the event of an emergency involving our facility, it is our policy to follow our Emergency Action Plan, which is linked with the Escambia County Emergency Management District Emergency Response Plan. Activation of this emergency response plan sets in motion a pre-planned series of events that notify all area emergency response agencies. Emergency response agencies are notified on the 911 system and directly. The 911 call is channeled through the Escambia County Sheriff's Department. All agencies and personnel respond to predetermined staging areas with representatives from each agency reporting to the Central Command Post (CP). A contingency plan is developed and executed using trained industry personnel along with other emergency response personnel from responding agencies, as needed.



Employees of this facility are issued copies of the Emergency Action Plan when initially hired and the plan is reviewed periodically. All of our operator

s at this facility have had the appropriate emergency response training as mandated by the OSHA standard. This plan and our emergency response policy have also been discussed with the local fire departments.



There have been no RMP incidents at the site within the past 5 years.





Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Diligent compliance with our RMP Prevention Program forms the framework on which we will continue to improve the level of safety at the Plains Dogwood Gas Plant Facility. Some of the key components of the safety improvements we expect to achieve are as follows:



    The Management of Change provisions ensures that we consider the potential safety and health impacts of any change we make to process chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures.



    The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) provisions serve as a tool to ensure continual evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in our safety standards.
